entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The data is from a survey of 998 Israeli adults conducted face to face from February 5 to March 11, 2025. Interviews were conducted in Hebrew and Arabic, and the survey is representative of the adult population ages 18 and older, excluding those in East Jerusalem and in outposts that are not sanctioned by the [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Maria Smerkovich, Research AssociateKelsey Jo Starr, Former Research AnalystAndrew Prozorovsky, Research Assistant Laura Clancy, Research AnalystAlan Cooperman, Director, Religion ResearchRachel (Weisel) Drian, Associate Director, CommunicationsJonathan Evans, Senior ResearcherMoira Fagan, Research AssociateJanell Fetterolf, Senior ResearcherShannon Greenwood, Digital Production ManagerAnna Jackson, [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Views of Israeli and Palestinian political leaders
entry.summary: Israelis' views of Netanyahu, Gantz and Lapid lean negative, and they have especially unfavorable views of Palestinian leaders. The post 4. Views of Israeli and Palestinian political leaders appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. The role of the international community
entry.summary: Israelis broadly agree that the U.S. is helpful in the work toward lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians, and that Iran is harmful. The post 3. The role of the international community appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of obstacles to peace
entry.summary: Most Israelis see lack of trust between Israelis and Palestinians and the status of Jerusalem as major obstacles to lasting peace. The post 2. Views of obstacles to peace appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Views of the potential for lasting peace
entry.summary: 56% of Israelis say their people are committed to lasting peace, but fewer say this of the Palestinian people or the leaders on either side. The post 1. Views of the potential for lasting peace appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Israeli Public Is Increasingly Skeptical About Lasting Peace
entry.summary: 21% of Israelis think Israel and a Palestinian state can coexist peacefully, the lowest share since 2013. The post Israeli Public Is Increasingly Skeptical About Lasting Peace appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Volcano tourism is booming, but is it too risky?
entry.summary:
On June 2, 2025, Italyâ€™s Mount Etna, one of Earthâ€™s most active volcanoes, erupted again, releasing what experts called a â€œlava fountainâ€ that sent tourists rushing downhill to safety.
In late March 2021, thousands of people in Iceland hiked into the Geldingadalur valley to watch fiery lava splutter and spill from the crater of the Fagradalsfjall volcano after it erupted for the first time in nearly 800 years.
As white ash clouds puffed above trails of glowing, molten rock inching through craggy black stones, some visitors took photos, others sat in quiet awe, and a few toasted marshmallows over the lava flows.
Photographer Chris Burkard, who captured the eruption for National Geographic, was transfixed by the ominous-but-beautiful landscape too. â€œIt was mesmerizing,â€ he sayâ€¦

entry.title: 10 of the best state parks in Maine
entry.summary:
Parkgoers looking to avoid the crowds at Acadia National Park can visit Maineâ€™s state parks, such as Quoddy Head State Park, home to the 3.6-mile Coastal Trail and the West Quoddy Head Lighthouse in Lubec. The stateâ€™s parks are often overshadowed by Acadia National Parkâ€”but they shouldnâ€™t be. These must-visit parks showcase the very best of the stateâ€™s natural wonders, from rugged coastlines and pristine wilderness.
In a state renowned for outstanding natural beauty and stunning landscapes, Acadia National Park, and Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument often overshadow Maineâ€™s state parks, but they shouldnâ€™t.
â€œMaineâ€™s state parks have everything: an iconic lighthouse guarding the bold coast at Quoddy Head, amazing beaches, and 4,000-foot mountains, like Old Speck and Kaâ€¦

entry.title: Japanâ€™s Ryukyu Islands are a nature loversâ€™ paradise
entry.summary:
The Ryukyu Islands are divided into three major island groups: Okinawa Islands, the Miyako Islands, and the Yaeyama Islands. The birthplace of karate also holds a deeply rooted connection to spirituality and nature. Hereâ€™s how to plan a visit to this stunning island archipelago.
As the legend goes, Japanâ€™s Ryukyu Islands were created by the goddess Amamikyo, who is believed to have descended from the heavens and into the sea, just off the southern coast of what is now known as the main island of Okinawa.Â
The Ryukyu Islands, located in the East China Sea, flourished for some 450-years as the semi-independent Ryukyu Kingdom. The islands served as a center of trade between Japan, China, and Southeast Asia until being officially designated a Japanese territory and renamed Okinawaâ€¦

entry.title: The essential guide to visiting Bermuda
entry.summary:
Bermuda features rich cultural traditions, historical landmarks, not-to-be-missed natural wonders, and more, making it the ideal tropical getaway for all types of travelers. World-class hotels, pink sand beaches, and lively year-around events make Bermuda a must-visit destination for any traveler.
Bermudaâ€™s famed pink sand beaches have drawn travelers to its shores for decades. Still, travelers shouldnâ€™t miss the rich cultural traditions, historical landmarks, and annual events that are just as alluring. The 21-square-mile island encompasses neighborhoods and natural wonders that provide enough options to inspire any trip.Â
Summer:Â Join the bacchanalia of Bermudaâ€™s annual Carnival celebration in June. Parties commence on boats and in the streets with soca music and reggaâ€¦

entry.title: Learning to live with the 800-pound bear next door
entry.summary:
The Mushkoh Valley in the north Indian region of Ladakh snakes twenty miles along mighty peaks near a contentious border. Â Â
Small villages of farmers and pastoralists dot the valley floor, all home to people of the Shina culture who trace their ancestry to the Mediterranean and Alexander the Greatâ€™s campaigns into central Asia over two thousand years ago.
Snow leopards, Tibetan wolves, foxes, ibex, and blue sheep live throughout the mountainous valley that enters a snow-covered deep freeze in the winter and becomes blanketed by vibrant wild tulips during the summer.
The valley is a natural paradise, but scattered shrapnel remains hidden underfoot and memories of conflict linger. In 1999, the quiet mountain valley garnered global attention when it became the frontline for thâ€¦

entry.title: Haiti: WFP concerned over humanitarian situation as hurricane season begins
entry.summary: As the hurricane season gets underway in the Caribbean, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) is sounding the alarm over Haitiâ€™s humanitarian situation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Aid for Syria, children under attack in Mozambique, rights-based climate action
entry.summary: Nearly 16 million people in Syria need urgent humanitarian health support, the UN warned on Tuesday, as aid deliveries continue amid escalating needs, deadly explosive hazards and a severe funding shortfall.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Five humanitarians killed in â€˜horrendousâ€™ attack on aid convoy in Sudan
entry.summary: An aid convoy carrying life-saving assistance for the famine-affected area of North Darfur, Sudan, was attacked on Monday night, killing five humanitarian workers, injuring many more and damaging critical humanitarian supplies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: As displacement surges in South Sudan, regional humanitarian crisis deepens
entry.summary: Since a sharp escalation in fighting in South Sudan in late February, 165,000 people have fled their homes, seeking safety either within the country or across borders, the UN refugee agency UNHCR said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: Rise in people fleeing to Chad as violence surges
entry.summary: The number of Sudanese refugees in Chad has more than tripled in just over two years amid the ongoing war in their homeland, the UN refugee agency UNHCR said in an alert on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Five countries elected to serve on UN Security Council
entry.summary: Bahrain, Colombia, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Latvia, and Liberia were elected on Tuesday to serve as non-permanent members of the UN Security Council, with two-year terms beginning in January 2026.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.summary: UN human rights chief Volker TÃ¼rkÂ has condemned new reports that dozens more Gazans were killed early Tuesday â€œtrying to access paltry amounts of foodâ€ around a private aid hub in the south of the enclave run by the US and Israel.

entry.title: Looking Back on Five Years: How the Sigma Awards Have Rallied and Inspired Data Journalism Excellence
entry.summary: After five years and 2,875 project entries from more than 100 countries, the Sigma Awards have become a catalyst for innovation and forever changed the face of data journalism.

entry.title: Thereâ€™s now a 50-50 chance this galaxy will crash into ours
entry.summary:
For more than a century, astronomers have watched the Andromeda galaxy, a massive swirl of neighboring stars, speed toward the Milky Way. And in recent years, measurements using the Hubble Space Telescope seemed to confirm a long-held prophecy: In about four or five billion yearsâ€™ time, the two galaxies will clash, ultimately merging into a colossal and unrecognizable new galaxy.
A fresh survey of both galaxies andâ€”cruciallyâ€”several of the other weighty galaxies in the same corner of the cosmos has now cast doubt on that calamitous outcome. The new forecast looked billions of years into the future and found that the odds of an Andromeda and Milky Way merger is about fifty-fifty.Â
â€œA coin flip is the more accurate description,â€ says Till Sawala, an astrophysicist at the Universityâ€¦

entry.title: Queen Victoria loved this UK islandâ€”and so will you
entry.summary:
A keen walker, poet Alfred Lord Tennyson was known for cutting a dash in his distinctive black cloak over the westerly downs, where youâ€™ll find hiking trails and a grand monument named in his honour. One-time haunt of Queen Victoria, the Isle of Wight has a host of unique charms, including dramatic sea stacks and a thriving population of red squirrels.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Package all thatâ€™s wonderful â€” and quite frankly quirky â€” about England, set it adrift in the English Channel, and youâ€™ll end up with the Isle of Wight. A UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, itâ€™s the UKâ€™s largest island and a microcosm of its heritage â€” all thatched cottages, centuries-old pubs and undulating landscapes. Some of the Victorian eraâ€™s most influential figureâ€¦

entry.title: Photo story: uncovering the charm of Bermuda
entry.summary: undefined undefined Bermuda's distinctive "boiler" reefs, seen here near the South Shore Beaches, create a churning effect in the water that resembles boiling. Bermuda sees an influx of part-time residents in the spring and summer: Longtails. These black-and-white tropicbirds, named for their long feathered tails, spend the winter at sea and return to Bermuda from March through August to nest in its cliffs and crevices. The traditional Gombey costume features a peacock feather headdress, painted mask, bells, and tassels, but each dancer adds their own twist to the ensemble. The word "Gombey" is thought to come from an African term meaning "rhythm," highlighting the role of drumming and percussive beats in their performances. undefined undefined For a birdâ€™s-eye view of Bermudaâ€™s reefs, landmarks, and distinctive fishhook shape, visitors can take to the skies with Heather Nicholds, owner of Blue Sky Flights. Nicholds offers 25-minute discovery flights and 45-minute full sightseeing tours around the island in her small plane. The view underground is equally stunning. In Bermudaâ€™s East End, the Crystal and Fantasy Caves invite visitors to explore the islandâ€™s subterranean wonders.

entry.title: A practical guide to island-hopping in Croatia
entry.summary:
Croatia's coastline is ideal for exploring by boat - smaller vessels can more easily access the Dalmatian islands' many hidden coves. With over 1,000 islands and an efficient ferry system, the Mediterranean country is a great island-hopping destination for travellers with time to spare. For tips on how to do it, try this handy guide.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). Island-hopping is a charming way to discover Croatia, allowing you to enjoy shots of espresso and shimmering sea views on deck as you sail from coast to coast. National ferry operator Jadrolinija and private competitors link most inhabited islands in the country. The majority of inter-island trips run during the daytime and vary in length from just 20 minutes to a few hoâ€¦

entry.title: Is this shopping mall the gayest place on Earth?
entry.summary:
Opened in 1982, the Yumbo Centrum in Spain's Canary Island bills itself as the worldâ€™s only LGBTQ+ mall. With four floors and 200 venues across 200,000 square feet, the Yumbo anchors a queer community remaking travel as a double-down embrace of their true selves. At the Yumbo Centrum in Spain's Canary Islands, Pride never ends.
Dario Villalba, 29,Â a shirtless actuary from Milan, roars into the night, jumping in a sweaty briar patch ofÂ men on a far-flung Spanish island. â€œSempre! Sempre!â€Â he cheers. â€œSempre di piÃ¹! Yumbo per sempre!â€ (â€œAlways and always! More and more! Yumbo forever!â€) As a Bruno Mars remix blares, Villalba revamps the chorus: â€œSleep tomorrow, but tonight go crazy. All you gotta do is just meet me at theâ€”'Yumbooooo.â€™â€
Opened in 1982 with the hope of â€œif youâ€¦

entry.title: World News in Brief: Guterres condemns antisemitic attacks, ILO to debate pros and cons of working online, Sudan, Ukraine updates
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Monday reinforced his stand against all acts of antisemitism following the horrific attack in Boulder, Colorado, at the weekend and vandalism in France targeting Jewish landmarks.

entry.title: UN calls for â€˜immediate and unconditionalâ€™ release of aid workers arbitrarily detained in Yemen
entry.summary: As June marks one year since the arbitrary detention of dozens of personnel from the UN, NGOs, civil society organizations and diplomatic missions by the Houthi de facto authorities in Yemen, the UN Secretary-General has reiterated his call for their release, urging they beÂ freed â€œimmediately and unconditionally.â€

entry.title: Deadly flooding in Nigeria displaces thousands
entry.summary: Flash flooding in western Nigeria at the weekend has caused devastation around the town of Mokwa in Niger state, leaving more than 150 dead and 3,000 people displaced â€“ more than half of whom are children aged 12 and under â€“ the UN said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Germanyâ€™s Annalena Baerbock elected President of the 80th General Assembly
entry.summary: Former German foreign minister Annalena Baerbock was elected President of the General Assemblyâ€™s 80th session on Monday. Her appointment comes as the regional group that includes Western Europe takes its turn at the helm of the world body.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Guterres urges probe into killings at food distribution sites
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General has called for an investigation into the killing and injury of Palestinians seeking food aid in Gaza on Sunday.

entry.summary: As Ukrainian and Russian delegations meet for a second round of preliminary peace talks in TurkÃ¯ye on Monday, rural communitiesÂ faced their own challenge: finding something to eat.

entry.title: Where to travel in July
entry.summary:
As schools go on holiday for the summer, July is the busiest month for travel in Europe. As the mercury rises and summer holidays commence, travel in July can be a family affair. And for those without young ones in tow, there are intrepid adventures to be had, from wildlife-watching in the Okavango Delta to seeing the Arctic tundra in bloom.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Let freedom ring: in July, European schools close for summer, marking the busiest month for travel on the continent. Cities buzz as people embrace the heat with outdoor cinemas and rooftop beer gardens, while ice cream vans sweeten up seaside towns. Families looking for sand and sea can beat the crowds by heading to the more serene European alternatives of Albania and Monteâ€¦

entry.title: Lifting of Israeli blockade â€˜the only way to avert mass starvationâ€™ in Gaza: UNRWA chief
entry.summary: Amid disputed reports of Israeli forces firing on civilians near a new privatised aid distribution point in southern Gaza, the head of the Palestine refugee agency, UNRWA, said on Sunday that lifting the months-long aid blockade of the enclave is the only way to avoid â€œmass starvationâ€.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Helpless in the face of hunger: Gaza families pray for deliverance â€“ or death
entry.summary: â€œI stood helpless in the face of my son's hunger. I cried a lot and told him to drink from our little water to satisfy his hunger,â€ said Zeenat, a young Palestinian woman speaking to UN News from the battered Gaza Strip.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: As AI evolves, pressure mounts to regulate â€˜killer robotsâ€™
entry.summary: A world in which algorithms determine the fate of soldiers and civilians alike is no longer hypothetical. AI-driven drones are reshaping warfare, raising deep ethical questions about autonomy in combat.Â As international policymakers scramble to set ground rules, the race is on to rein in this rapidly evolving technology.

entry.title: Is this Canadian festival the best place to see grey whales?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Stand on the western shores of Vancouver Island in March and youâ€™ll spot some of British Columbiaâ€™s most famous visitors. Each spring, thousands of grey whales glide past this stretch of coast on their journey from the warm breeding waters of Mexico to the nutrient-rich waters of Alaska â€” a round trip of up to 15,000 miles, making it the longest mammal migration on Earth.
In the mid-1980s, Brian Congdon, a resident of Ucluelet on the west coast of Vancouver Island, had an idea. He wanted to celebrate this natural spectacle with a home-grown festival, much like those heâ€™d seen in California. Drawing on his experience running a whale-watching tour company, he brought together volunteers and local authorities, devisedâ€¦

entry.title: Why the Balkans should be your next summer destination
entry.summary:
To beat the crowds and chase adventure, plan a trip to the smaller, less-explored countries of the Western Balkans â€” here are five to explore. The final frontier of Europe is this southeastern peninsula, where travellers can find Roman palaces, old Ottoman quarters, aquamarine bays and dramatic mountain hikes â€” but far fewer crowds.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
A complicated region with an extraordinarily rich cultural heritage, Europeâ€™s beautiful Balkan lands have been passed through and fought over by civilisations including the Romans, Greeks and Ottomans for more than a millennium. As a result, the term â€˜Balkansâ€™ is one of the slipperiest geographical descriptions in Europe. Broadly speaking it applies to the peninsula that stretcâ€¦

entry.title: These 4,500-year-old rattles may be among the worldâ€™s oldest toys
entry.summary:
Archaeologist Mette Marie Hald holds fragments of 4,500-year-old rattles found at the Hama site in Syria. Hald and her colleagues suspect that the rattles and others like them were used to sooth children rather than to make music, as some have previously suggested. A new study argues that ancient rattles unearthed in Syria arenâ€™t musical instruments, but toys used to entertain infants. â€œToday, we use screens, back then it was rattles.â€
Clay rattles made in Syria about 4,500 years ago were designed to â€œamuse and calmâ€ infants, according to a new study. But some archaeologists think they were used in rituals to dispel evil spirits, or that they might have served both purposes.
â€œThey have little handles that are too small for me, and I have quite small hands,â€ says archaeoloâ€¦

entry.title: Climbing Mount Everest may get even harder
entry.summary:
Mount Everest and Lhotse are seen through Buddhist prayer flags in Nepal. A new proposal from Nepal aims to tighten requirements and improve climber safety on the world's tallest peak, but such proposals rarely become law.
Last month, as the 2025 climbing season began on Mount Everest, Nepalâ€™s upper house of Parliament introduced a tourism bill that includes a suite of new rules that would significantly raise the bar for who is allowed to attempt the mountain, who can guide, and how much it will cost.Â Â
This yearâ€™s proposal includes a mandate that Everest hopefuls must first climb a 7,000-meter peak located in Nepal, as well as requirements for all guides to be Nepalese citizens, for medical certificates confirming good health to be obtained from approved in-country facilitiesâ€¦

entry.title: How the Council of Nicaea changed Christianity forever
entry.summary:
This May marks 1,700 years since the convening of what is arguably the most important and influential council in Christian history. For three months in 325 CE, Emperor Constantine gathered hundreds of bishops from across the empire in Nicaea, on the northern coast of what is now Turkey. The resulting statement of beliefâ€”the Nicene Creedâ€”was the first official declaration of Christian faith and remains foundational for Christians around the world to this day. Attend Sunday school or a Christian church of nearly any denomination, and you will encounter principles derived from the Nicene Creed.
The task of the council was enormous: to establish correct Christian doctrine, fix the date of Easter, define episcopal jurisdictions, and devise protocols for addressing local schisms and disseâ€¦

entry.title: You really are a mosquito magnet. Hereâ€™s what you can do.
entry.summary: Colored scanning electron micrograph of a female specimen of the mosquito species, Anopheles gambiae. This micrograph shows the mosquito's bulging abdomen, swollen after a meal of human blood. New research proves these bloodsuckers can pick you out in a crowd. Here are the odors theyâ€™re drawn to, what scientists recommend to keep them awayâ€”and how a future personalized repellant might work. Mosquitoes love Kim Zarins. The insectsâ€™ preference for Zarins, an English professor at Sacramento State University, is so extreme that her 20-year-old son likes her to come outside with him because she serves as a decoy and â€œhe knows heâ€™ll be safe,â€ Zarins says. But now, mosquito magnets like Zarins are helping scientists pinpoint what entices these thirsty bloodsuckers, and thâ€¦

entry.title: How this California Gold Rush town became an LGBTQ+ haven
entry.summary:
Since the early to mid-1800s, Nevada City has been a haven for many people in California and beyond, including LGBTQ+ travelers and transplants. Prospectors came to Nevada City for gold, but the forested community has become an enduring oasis for artists, musicians, and bohemians.
When the first settlers came to the Sierra Nevada foothills in the late 1840s, they came for gold. Decades after the California Gold Rush ended in 1855, a different crop of settlersâ€”including artists, musicians, and LGBTQ+ peopleâ€”came looking for something other than precious metal.Â
History runs deep in Nevada City, a hilly, pine-scented community of barely 3,000, which boomed in 1849 upon the arrival ofÂ early settlersÂ like Captain John Pennington and William McCaig. During its heyday, miners came aâ€¦

entry.title: Why June is the best month to visit this U.S. Virgin Island
entry.summary:
St. Thomas in June brings calmer waters, cheaper hotels, turtle sightings, and more room to stretch out. The best place in the Caribbean for a passport-free tropical escape offers up great weather, fewer crowds, and hotel rates up to half off in the shoulder season.
It turns out that the grass actually isÂ greener in St. Thomasâ€”sea turtle grass, that is, for those traveling in June. This sweet spot, after the bustle and beats of carnival season concludes across most of the Caribbean, is both an ecologistâ€™s paradise and a deal-hunterâ€™s delight.
Canopies of fire-red flamboyant flowersÂ blanket the island, complementing the hue of mangoes that hang lush and ripe. Nesting season starts for green sea turtles, which are drawn not only to shore to lay their eggs, but to the shallow-watâ€¦

entry.title: 10 places to stay while you're at Yosemite National Park
entry.summary:
Situated at the base of a granite rock cliff, the Ahwahnee Hotel opened in 1927 and is an example of the National Park Service's rustic architecture, also known as â€œparkitecture.â€ This hotel is just one of 10 incredible places to stay when visiting Yosemite National Park. Choose your own adventure: a rustic tent cabin at the base of Half Dome or a lavish lodge just outside the national parkâ€™s gate.
Yosemite National ParkÂ welcomes approximately four million visitors every year. Not surprisingly, travelers from around the world are drawn to the 748,000 acres of natural beauty which include Yosemite Valley, Half Dome, El Capitan, Glacier Point, numerous waterfalls, and Mariposa Grove, where visitors can walk through a giant sequoia. With so much to see and do, visitors to the nationalâ€¦

entry.title: How Sally Ride blazed a trail for women in space
entry.summary:
Sally Ride sits in the aft flight deck mission specialist's seat during deorbit preparations. On June 18, 1983, Sally Ride became the first American woman to fly in space when the space shuttle Challenger launched on mission STS-7. As one of the three mission specialists on the mission, Ride played a vital role in helping the crew deploy communications satellites, conduct experiments, and make use of the first Shuttle Pallet Satellite. In June 1983, this barrier-breaking astronaut overcame discriminatory policiesâ€”and a sexist societyâ€”as the first American woman to launch into orbit.
On June 18, 1983, Sally Ride would become the first American woman to launch into space. She had already survived NASA's grueling training and a barrage of tests, but there was another hurdle to cross â€¦

entry.title: Earthâ€™s Most Interesting Animals
entry.summary:
Before your visit, discover some of Earth's most captivating creatures found at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park, like the stealthy Sumatran tiger, the soaring California condor, and the resilient desert tortoiseâ€”each with its own fascinating traits that you can observe during your safari adventure.
The southern white rhino, nearly 99 percent of which are found in South Africa, Kenya, Namibia, and Zimbabwe, is one of the largest land animals on Earth, second only to elephants. Despite the name, these rhinos are gray, and "white" was likely derived from the Afrikaans word for "wide," referring to their broad, square mouths. These semi-social animals often live in groups; males are usually solitary and mark their territory with dung. White rhinos are grazers, and enjoy rolling in mudâ€¦

entry.title: â€˜This is not just iceâ€™: Glaciers support human livelihoods, UN deputy chief says
entry.summary: UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed called for urgent action to protect water-related ecosystems in remarks to the International Conference on Glaciersâ€™ Preservation in Dushanbe, Tajikistan, on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UNâ€™s lifesaving programmes under threat as budget crisis hits hard
entry.summary: The UN is facing a deepening budget crisis that threatens lifesaving operations worldwide. From refugee aid in Mozambique to maternal health services in Afghanistan, critical programmes are on the brink of collapse unless urgent funding is secured.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Justice is long overdueâ€™: Guterres calls for reparations for enslavement and colonialism
entry.summary: Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres renewed his calls for Member states and the United Nations to work towards justice and reparations for Africans and the diaspora in a speech in New York on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Education suffers amid DR Congo violence, WHO greenlights RSV vaccines, more hurricanes ahead for Haiti
entry.summary: In Ituri, a province in the east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), intensifying conflict, intercommunal violence and mass displacement are forcing hundreds of thousands of children out of school.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Songs of hope rise from Gazaâ€™s ruins
entry.summary: In Al-Jundi Al-Majhool Square â€“ once the bustling heart of Gaza City â€“ music now floats among the tents. The square, transformed into a sprawling displacement camp, shelters hundreds of families driven from their homes by more than 19 months of war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: How to plan the ultimate island-hopping adventure in Croatia
entry.summary:
Whatever youâ€™re looking for, youâ€™ll find it in Croatia's islands â€” from buzzy resorts for a party crowd on Hvar to towns like KorÄula or Rab, their streets an insouciant jumble of gothic and Renaissance beauty. In between are endless pine-scrubbed specks with no firm grip on the 21st century, washed by the cleanest waters in the Mediterranean. Known as the land of a thousand islands, Croatiaâ€™s Dalmatia and Kvarner archipelagoes offer an abundance of coastal adventures â€” from exploring a little-known National Park to swimming in a cave plucked from Odyssean legend.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The fascination of islands is that they appear to be distinct, self-contained worlds. If thatâ€™s true, then Croatia is practically its own solar systeâ€¦

entry.title: Why some people struggle to form mental images
entry.summary:
Close your eyes and imagine an apple.
Can you see its shape? What color is it? Is it floating in the air, or being held by a hand, or sitting on a table?
If you find yourself struggling, you might have arecently coined condition called aphantasia.Â
People with aphantasia, or â€œaphants,â€ say they lack the ability to effectively visualize in their mindâ€™s eye. They might have vivid imaginations, and lead very creative lives, but their brains work a little differently when it comes to visual imagery.
Twenty-five years ago, Adam Zeman, a professor of cognitive and behavioral neurology previously at the University of Exeter, now an honorary fellow at the Centre for Clinical Brain Sciences in Edinburgh, was introduced to the curious case of a man who had lost the ability to visâ€¦

entry.title: Where to stay in Porto
entry.summary:
The Yeatman is one of many unique accommodation options in the Portuguese city of Porto. Portugalâ€™s second city is riding a wave and its hotel scene is equal to the task, with wine-themed haunts up to palatial pads.


This article was adapted from National Geographic Traveller (UK) In a city dominated by independent hotels, Porto offers a plethora of unique and interesting boutique places to stay. From converted warehouses and 19th-century palaces to properties in and around the famous wine district, youâ€™re neâ€¦

entry.title: Who was Sacagawea? The real story of her life and legacy
entry.summary:
Explorer Sacagawea stares into the distance while Jean Baptiste Charbonneau sleeps soundly on her back. She was vital to the Lewis and Clark Expedition after the Louisiana Purchase. Often remembered merely for guiding Lewis and Clark, Sacagaweaâ€™s story is far more complex. Discover the deeper story behind the life of this Shoshone womanâ€”beyond the expedition.
Of all the figures that emerged from theÂ American West, none may be so wrapped in mythology as Sacagawea. When she joined Meriwether Lewis and William Clark's infamous expedition west, she was just a teenager and a new mother. However, Sacagawea emerged as an icon of the New World.
Today, her name is synonymous with a period characterized by rapid westward expansion at the great expense of the Tribal Nations who stewardeâ€¦

entry.title: Inside Chile's wild and beautiful Juan FernÃ¡ndez Islands
entry.summary:
On a recent visit to Chile's Juan FernÃ¡ndez Islands, National Geographic photographer Andy Mann found himself surrounded by hundreds of playful locals: endemic Juan FernÃ¡ndez fur seals. Once thought to be extinct, the seals are believed to number more than 200,000, far exceeding the islands' human population of under a thousand. And the blubbery denizens are not shy about approaching divers.
"It's probably the most joyous, childlike diving I've ever doneâ€”like getting in the water with 500 puppies," says Mann. "They're so curious and charismatic."
The dive was one of many highlights of Mann's trip to Juan FernÃ¡ndez, an archipelago of three islands teeming with endemic plants and animals â€” including the seals, orange-feathered Juan FernÃ¡ndez firecrown hummingbirds, and two vulnerabâ€¦

author.name: Christina Nunez, Andy Mann, Kyle Roepke

entry.title: These destinations inspired the most popular video games
entry.summary: Valley of the Kings near Luxor, Egypt, is featured in popular video games such as Indiana Jones and the Great Circle and Assassinâ€™s Creed: Origins, inspiring gamers to add the historic destination to their travel bucket list. Video game tourism is on the rise as the gamesâ€™ immersive and interactive worlds spark wanderlust in their biggest fans. From Oslo to Tokyo, here are eight places where gamers can level up. At least 35 percent of U.S. travelers are inspired to book a trip overseas based on a video game they've played, according to Skyscannerâ€™sÂ recent survey As technology becomes more accessible and sophisticated, video games continue to gain points other traditional media canâ€™t quite reach.Â May NaidooÂ is not surprised. Heâ€™s a filmmaker and PokÃ©mon Partner wâ€¦

entry.title: Towel art has risen to a whole new level
entry.summary:
As any traveler can attest to, itâ€™s the unique touches in hotel rooms and cruise cabins that make a trip that much more memorable. For both adults and children, there's nothing more uplifting than walking into your room to find a towel folded into the shape of a lovable animal. But how did the art form of origami make its way to the hospitality industry?
The history of origami is as complex as the intricately folded paper. Many scholars believe that the invention of paper in China, around 100 B.C.E., coincided with the first attempts at paper folding. It was the Japanese who made origami, originally known as orikata, a large part of their culture. Because paper was very expensive, the art form was mostly used for religious rituals by the wealthy, including wrapping offerings to the goâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 169 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from April 28 to May 4, 2025. A total of 5,085 panelists responded out of 5,772 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 160 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted Jan. 8-19, 2025, among a sample of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) U.S. adults. A total of [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: The Pew Research Center is a subsidiary of The Pew Charitable Trusts, its primary funder. This report was made possible with support from the Trusts and from the People & Voices Initiative. Â This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at pewresearch.org/topic/gender-lgbtq. [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Community, friends and LGBTQ spaces
entry.summary: We asked LGBTQ Americans some questions to better understand: Connections to a broader LGBTQ community About a quarter of LGBTQ adults (23%) say they feel extremely or very connected to a broader LGBTQ community. Another 42% feel somewhat connected, and 35% feel not too or not at all connected. Views on this vary by: How [â€¦] The post 5. Community, friends and LGBTQ spaces appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. LGBTQ identities
entry.summary: To better understand how LGBTQ adults identify, we asked respondents three separate questions: When it comes to sexual orientation, more than half of LGBTQ adults (55%) describe themselves as bisexual. Four-in-ten are gay or lesbian, while small shares are straight (1%) or something else (3%). About one-in-ten LGBTQ adults (9%) are transgender. This includes 4% [â€¦] The post 4. LGBTQ identities appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Experiences with coming out as gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender
entry.summary: To better understand the coming out experiences of gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender adults, we asked them: Half or more in each group say they knew they were gay, lesbian, bisexual or trans before age 14. Far fewer say they first told someone by that age. Small shares ranging from 1% to 4% across these [â€¦] The post 3. Experiences with coming out as gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Personal experiences with acceptance and discrimination
entry.summary: We asked LGBTQ adults whether they feel accepted by their family, friends and co-workers, and about their experiences with discrimination based on their LGBTQ identity. Some LGBTQ adults are not out to different people in their lives. Varying shares say no one in each of the following groups knows about their sexual orientation or gender [â€¦] The post 2. Personal experiences with acceptance and discrimination appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Ukraine: Hopes for peace on life support, Security Council hears
entry.summary: A glimmer of hope for peace in Ukraine has been overshadowed by a devastating new wave of Russian attacks, UN officials told the Security Council on Thursday, warning of soaring civilian casualties and a worsening humanitarian crisis that could derail a diplomatic end to the war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN searches for solutions to global housing crisis
entry.summary: The UNâ€™s urban development agencyÂ estimates that an astonishing 2.8 billion people worldwide lack access to adequate housing, secure land, and basic water and sanitation services â€“ thatâ€™s around 40 per cent of the global population.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜We are the presentâ€™: Tajik climate activist urges leaders to include youth voices in dialogue
entry.summary: A young activist from Tajikistan is speaking up to show that her generation can be part of the solution to combat climate change.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Desperate hunger drives crowd to storm UN food warehouse in Gaza
entry.summary: Desperate hunger drove crowds of people to overrun a World Food Programme (WFP) warehouse in central Gaza on Wednesday, reportedly leaving two dead and several injured in a chaotic scramble for food.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN honours service and sacrifice of its peacekeepers
entry.summary: The United Nations is honouring staff serving at its field missions through several events to mark the International Day of UN Peacekeepers on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Winners revealed: National Geographic Traveller (UK) Photography Competition 2025
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Â Seeking to highlight the best in travel photography, this prestigious annual competition, celebrating its 12th year, was open to entrants from across the UK and Ireland. Photographers, both amateur and professional, submitted travel images taken during the past year in any of six categories: Landscape, People, Wildlife, Food, City life and Portfolio.Â
Pat Riddell, editor of National Geographic Traveller (UK), said: â€œOur competition goes from strength to strength, with this yearâ€™s easily one of the strongest yet. World-class photography remains at the heart of the National Geographic brand, and the winners happily sit in that category.Â
â€œCapturing everything from the dramatic landscapes of Iceland and Italy toâ€¦

entry.title: Tips for Turning Unreadable Text Into Evidence
entry.summary: Whether it's extracting names from footage, decoding social media posts, or reading distorted text in documents, Henk van Ess explains how free digital tools can take on these investigative tasks.

entry.title: Video: How religious are young Americans today?
entry.summary: Young adults today are less religious than older adults by traditional measures. But when it comes to spirituality, the differences are smaller. The post Video: How religious are young Americans today? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 9 celestial events lighting up the night sky this June
entry.summary:
Whether youâ€™re waking up early to spot Venus in the pre-dawn sky, staying up late to peep the Lagoon Nebula, or spending the whole night on the hunt for meteors, Juneâ€™s night sky has something for every stargazer. Hereâ€™s what to keep an eye out for when you look up this month.
(9 must-see night sky events to look forward to in 2025.)
On June 1, Venus will reach its farthest distance west of the sun from the perspective of Earthâ€”a point known as greatest western elongation. This is a particularly good time to get a glimpse at Earthâ€™s neighboring planet, as it wonâ€™t be drowned out by sunlight.
In some time zones, the exact timing of this event occurs on May 31, while in others, it's on June 1. But the best time to view Venus is just before dawn, when it rises in the eastern â€¦

entry.title: Need to unwind? This new travel trend adds a twist.
entry.summary:
Taking action to restore and care for nature sparks the brainâ€™s reward circuits, fostering a lasting sense of purpose and connection. Wellness-centric travel has long been popular, with numerous health studies touting the benefits of spending more time in nature. A new evolution of the trend puts wildlife at the centerâ€”responsibly.
In todayâ€™s fast-paced and tech-dominated world, people are plugged into the conveniences of modern day life, but theyâ€™re as disconnected as ever, overlooking the simple joys of nature and the wellness benefits it can offer us. You could say that the more high-tech we become, the more nature we undoubtedly need. The practice of forest bathing to cultivate relaxation and ward off the effects of stress and anxiety is well-established, but next-level nature â€¦

entry.title: These are the best stargazing sites in North America
entry.summary:
Both urban and rural areas are darkening their skies to boost astrotourism. These dark sky sanctuaries, reserves, parks, and trails invite you to immerse yourself in the wonders of our night skies. Hereâ€™s where to go.
Travelers are increasingly lifting their eyes to nighttime skies in search of impressive celestial phenomena and, perhaps, more. â€œLooking up at the night sky is sort of what makes us human,â€ says Ruskin Hartley, the executive director of DarkSky International, a nonprofit group based in Tucson, Arizona. â€œWe have done it for millennia. Every single culture has told their first stories in the stars overhead, and they found meaning in the stars. Today, the vast majority of people are robbed of that.â€
On a clear night last November, I spent over two hours in a dome aâ€¦

entry.title: Explore the UK through its family-friendly summer festivals
entry.summary:
Sewing camps and sensory gardens will be at this yearâ€™s Camp Bestival. Music festivals in the UK are doing more than ever to cater to all interests and ages. Here are this summerâ€™s family-friendly highlights.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Music festivals are doing more than ever to cater to all interests and ages. Younger audiences are often won over purely by the fact that attendance typically involves camping, glamping or pitching up in a caravan â€” an opportunity to sleep out in the wild. But the UKâ€™s best festivals also provide an endless roster of activities, workshops and experiences to help families bond and create lasting memories. From chilled countryside escapes to adrenaline-sparking coastal adventures. Here are the golden ticketsâ€¦

entry.title: The worldâ€™s plastic pollution crisis, explained
entry.summary:
Plastic trash drifts in the ocean in the Philippines. Much of the planet is swimming in discarded plastic, which is harming animal and possibly human health. Can plastic pollution be cleaned up?
Plastic pollution has become one of the most pressing environmental issues, thanks to the overwhelming rise in production of disposable plastic products.
Plastic pollution is most visible in developing Asian and African nations, where garbage collection systems are often inefficient or nonexistent. But the developed world, especially in countries with low recycling rates, also has trouble properly collecting discarded plastics.
Plastic trash has become so ubiquitous it has prompted efforts to write a global treaty negotiated by the United Nations.
Plastics made from fossil â€¦

entry.title: David Burnham-TRAC Data Reporting Fellowship
entry.summary: ProPublica is looking for a motivated early-career investigative data journalist to join our editorial team as the David Burnham-TRAC Data Reporting Fellow, specifically focused on investigating the federal bureaucracy. entry.title: Pandemics to pollution: WHO Assembly delivers landmark health decisions
entry.summary: The 78th World Health Assembly concluded Tuesday in Geneva, marking several major milestones in global health. Delegates adopted the worldâ€™s first pandemic agreement and approved a significant boost in core funding for the World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war exacerbates risk of cholera and malaria: UNICEF
entry.summary: The UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) has warned of an escalating public health crisis in Sudan, as conflict and mass displacement continue to drive a surge in disease, particularly cholera and malaria.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen: UN warns against Houthi-Israel escalation, calls for dialogue
entry.summary: The United Nations has called for restraint following another wave of escalation between Houthi rebels in Yemen and Israeli forces.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN awards 2025 Mandela Prize to Brenda Reynolds and Kennedy Odede
entry.summary: An IndigenousÂ social worker from Canada and a social entrepreneur from Kenya are the laureates of the 2025 Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela Prize, the United Nations announced on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜My husband died in my armsâ€™: Russian drone attacks on Ukrainians amount to crimes against humanity, UN investigators report
entry.summary: Russian drone attacks against civilians in the Kherson region of Ukraine constitute crimes against humanity and war crimes, independent UN human rights investigators concluded in a report published on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜We are women like youâ€™: UN honours peacekeepers for work in gender empowerment
entry.summary: In early summer 2024, Squadron Leader Sharon Mwinsote Syme of Ghana ventured into sector North of Abyei, a disputed region between Sudan and South Sudan where she was deployed as a military gender advocate with the UN Interim Security Force in Abyei (UNISFA).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Top UN envoy calls on Israel to end devastating strikes, starvation of civilians
entry.summary: Gazaâ€™s population is being â€œstarved and denied the very basics,â€ while the region stands at a dangerous crossroads, the UNâ€™s Middle East peace envoy warned the Security Council Wednesday, urging immediate action to halt the violence, restore aid and advance a two-State solution before time runs out.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN aid teams plead for access amid reports Gazans shot collecting food
entry.summary: In Gaza, dozens of Palestinians have been reportedly injured and shot trying to collect aid from the new US and Israeli-backed aid distribution facility operating independently of the UN.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Climate change: World likely to breach 1.5Â°C limit in next five years
entry.summary: Fact: 2024 was the warmest year on record â€“ but the heat is far from over. A new report from the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) warns that global temperatures will likely continue rising, with an 80 per cent chance that at least one year between now and 2029 will be even hotter.

entry.title: How did this shark swim a record-breaking 4,000 miles?
entry.summary:
Bull sharks tend to be aggressive and live near shorelines, which has earned them fearsome reputations. One eight-foot-long female recently logged a record breaking 4,000-mile journey. Along her migration from Mozambique to Nigeria, the eight-foot-long female would have encountered a zone of water too cold to cross that has kept Africa's bull shark populations separated for 55,000 years.
When Turawa Hakeem caught a bull shark near Lagos, Nigeria last summer, the Ghanaian captain had no idea his crew was reeling a record winner onto his wooden fishing boat.
The eight-foot-long female had made an epic journey of at least 4,500 miles, the longest known movement of its species and the first time a bull shark was documented swimming through two oceans. The shark traveled from the Mâ€¦

entry.title: Frozen shoulder is a real conditionâ€”and it mostly affects women
entry.summary:
Frozen shoulder is straightforwardâ€”the condition means stiffness and difficulty in raising the arm. It can be caused by partial tears in the shoulder's tendon, as represented in this MRI scan. The painful affliction known as adhesive capsulitis can last for yearsâ€”but has long been ignored by medical researchers who doubted its existence. New treatments may finally promise a cure.
Stirrups, Pap smears, prenatal checks: At her busy office at Duke Womenâ€™s Health in Durham, NC, OB-GYNÂ Anne Fordâ€™s work with female patients of all ages usually takes place from the waist down.
But Ford has noticed that a subset of her patientsâ€”all women entering or past menopauseâ€”come to their appointments with a seemingly non-gynecological issue: adhesive capsulitis or â€œfrozen shoulder,â€ a poorly unâ€¦

entry.title: These intimate safari camps offer a peek into Maasai culture
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œSimba!â€ The urgent whisper â€” â€˜lionâ€™ in Swahili â€” comes from Julius Naurori as he stands bolt upright in the back of our 4WD like a human antenna.
Immediately, our guide in the front slows the car to a cautious prowl and a hush descends, save for the tinkling silver discs tied to Juliusâ€™s waist as they sway in time with the rocking of the car. The dawn sky is still blushing crimson, and at first itâ€™s hard to see whatâ€™s almost directly in front of us: four sleeping lions, their chocolate manes camouflaged as they lie on their sides in long, unruly grass marking the banks of the Mara River.
Our guide is Roca River Camp co-owner Ross Withey, and Julius, our wildlife-spotter, is his wingman on this safari drive inâ€¦

entry.title: These remote desert oases are Egyptâ€™s hidden gems
entry.summary:
Siwa Oasis, a 12-hour drive from Cairo, is worth the trip to swim and float in hundreds of salt lakes and natural hot springs. Most visitors never experience the natural masterpieces that lie off the tourist trailâ€”from bubbling hot springs to unearthly landscapes of dead volcanoes to the â€œValley of the Whales.â€
The world knows Egypt for the Pyramids of Giza and cosmopolitan Cairo, the tourist-trodden temples of Luxor, and Red Sea resort towns. These coastal and Nile River Valley destinations are a narrow view of a country thatâ€™s 90 percent desert.
Few travelers venture into that 90 percent. The vast Western Desert, which blends into Libya and beyond, is Egyptâ€™s great unknown. Adventurers since Alexander the Great have braved the harsh clime and been rewarded with the untouchedâ€¦

entry.title: UN aims to transform urgency into action at Nice Ocean Conference
entry.summary: Countries are uniting in the French city of Nice next month to save the marine environment.

entry.summary: The Golden Triangle â€“ the remote, jungle-covered border region where Thailand, Myanmar, and the Lao Peopleâ€™s Democratic Republic meet â€“ has seen an exponential surge in the illicit manufacture and trafficking of synthetic drugs.

entry.summary: The UN International Organization for Migration (IOM) has welcomed recent decisions by the United States, the United Kingdom and the European Union to ease sanctions against Syria.

entry.title: Sudan conflict triggers regional health crisis, warns WHO
entry.summary: As the war between rival militaries in Sudan continues, the World Health Organization (WHO) has raised alarm over the escalating health emergency, driven by ongoing violence, mass displacement, collapsing health systems and poor conditions inside refugee camps.

entry.summary: A seasoned diplomat and legal scholar from Jordan was elected on Tuesday to serve as a judge at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), the United Nationsâ€™ principal judicial body.

entry.title: Real cost of disasters is 10 times higher than previously thought, says UN
entry.summary: As countries face increasingly steep bills from natural hazards, the true cost of disasters is actually 10 times higher than previously estimated, with far-reaching effects across healthcare, housing, education and employment.

entry.summary: Reports indicated on Tuesday that Israelâ€™s controversial aid distribution plan had begun in Gaza as the United Nations called once again on the Israeli authorities to allow an â€œimmediate surgeâ€ in the amount of supplies reaching the enclave to prevent starvation.

entry.title: 8 of the best beach cities in Spain
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
High-spirited northern surf hubs, relaxed Mediterranean-fronting neighbourhoods and glowing sands washed by the thundering Atlantic â€” mainland Spainâ€™s cities can offer all of this and more. Take your pick of these varied urban beauties, scattered around the countryâ€™s 3,000-mile peninsular coast. Beaches in Spain can get packed everywhere during the high season, from July to August, so for the best chance of solitude and space, itâ€™s worth travelling in the quieter shoulder periods.
A pair of wide gold beaches, tucked into a crescent-moon bay between forested headlands, sets the scene for one of northern Spainâ€™s most popular coastal escapes. Many San SebastiÃ¡n strolls begin on the promenade curving past Playa de Onâ€¦

entry.title: Are airline loyalty schemes worth it?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
When British Airways (BA) launched its revamped frequent-flyer scheme on 1 April, it probably didnâ€™t anticipate the furore that would follow. The new logo and name change â€” a contraction from the Executive Club to simply the Club â€” were uncontroversial. Instead, the outcry concerned the airline changing the way it plans to reward its customers.
Like most airline loyalty schemes, BA rewards its customers with two sets of points. The first, reward points â€”Â known as Avios in BAâ€™s case â€” are essentially an airline currency, and you can save these over months or years and redeem them for cheap flights and upgrades. The second, loyalty points, which BA calls Tier points, are collected over a single year and will move youâ€¦

entry.title: UN warns of â€˜catastrophicâ€™ human rights crisis in Myanmar as violence and economic collapse deepen
entry.summary: Myanmarâ€™s spiralling human rights crisis â€“ fuelled by relentless military violence, systemic impunity and economic collapse â€“ has left civilians caught in the crossfire of an increasingly brutal conflict, according to a new report by the UN human rights office (OHCHR).

entry.title: UN rights chief calls for end to daily killings in Ukraine after deadly weekend attacks
entry.summary: The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights has called for an immediate end to the daily killings and destruction in Ukraine, following a weekend of deadly attacks that left at least 14 civilians â€“ including three children â€“ dead and dozens more injured across the country.

entry.title: Top marks for Lebanon schools project helping marginalised kids
entry.summary: An inclusive education programme in Lebanon is getting top marks from teachers and students, especially children with disabilities who are often the most marginalised.

entry.title: Whatâ€™s your poison? Alcohol linked to higher risk of pancreatic cancer
entry.summary: Alcoholic drinks, especially beer and spirits, may raise the risk of pancreatic cancer, a new UN study has found.

entry.title: Gazansâ€™ suffering goes on amid intensifying Israeli strikes
entry.summary: After another deadly weekend of Israeli attacks in Gaza, aid teams stressed once again on Monday that the â€œtrickleâ€ of supplies being allowed into the war-torn enclave will not halt famine.

entry.title: UN rights mission deplores deadly Russian strikes in Ukraine
entry.summary: The UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) has deplored a deadly wave of Russian missile and drone strikes that reportedly killed at least 13 civilians and injured 65 others, warning that the attack underscores the grave risks of using powerful explosive weapons in populated areas.

entry.title: Explore New Zealand one scenic drive at a time
entry.summary:
Life moves at a slower pace in New Zealand so taking your time while hitting the wide-open road is the best way to experience it. Starting from the countryâ€™s main gateways, such as Auckland and Christchurch, these road trips offer the best chance to experience the wealth and breadth of New Zealandâ€™s unparalleled landscapes.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
In Aotearoa (the MÄori name for New Zealand, which is often translated as â€˜the land of the long white cloudâ€™), life moves at a slower pace so taking your time while hitting the wide-open road is the best way to experience it. Meander through mountain ranges and past pancake rocks to wineries and whale-watching spots on New Zealandâ€™s wild South Island, while on the North Island, take a leisurâ€¦

entry.title: Is Sasquatch real? Some Harrison Hot Springs residents say yes
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Henry Williams wasnâ€™t always a believer in the Sasquatch. Growing up, he had of course heard the tales of old â€” of a legendary hairy, bipedal primate said to roam the forests at sundown. Yet for much of his life, 76-year-old Henry had shrugged these stories off without much thought. They were used to remind youngsters to come home before nightfall, heâ€™d reasoned. All that changed, however, on the day that the Sasquatch came to pay him a visit two decades ago, near his home in Squamish in southwest British Columbia.
â€œIt threw a huge boulder into the middle of a nearby river,â€ says Henry, flinging his arms wide to imitate an almighty splash as we chat in the lobby of the Harrison Hot Springs Resort, a historic hotel â€¦

entry.title: Thousands flee homes in Mozambique as conflict and disasters fuel worsening crisis
entry.summary: More than 25,000 people have been forced to flee their homes in northern Mozambique in recent weeks, as conflict and a series of disasters fuel a worsening humanitarian crisis â€“ one that risks deepening as vital relief operations face a severe funding shortfall.

entry.title: 6 of the best rail adventures in British Columbia
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
British Columbia, Canadaâ€™s westernmost province, is well known for its spectacular landscapes, offering endless views of serrated peaks, opaline glacier lakes and feather-tipped pines. And what better way to take it all in than on a train, with those big-picture vistas slowly rolling by beyond the windowpanes â€” here are some of the best rail routes to try.
Vancouver to Banff; 2 days This double-decker train is surely one of the worldâ€™s most scenic rail journeys, offering bubble-domed vistas of mountains, lakes, forests, gorges, rivers and glaciers and the chance to spot wildlife along the way. The classic First Passage to the West route follows part of the line from the historic Canadian Pacific Railway, Canadaâ€™sâ€¦

entry.title: Where to find Ireland's best food? Head west.
entry.summary:
Across County Corkâ€™s wide and quiet expanse of gently rolling hills and craggy coastline, a culinary renaissance is unfolding, led by dairy farmers, foragers, fish smokers, and chefs. Here, Irelandâ€™s soul and story are best understood on the plate.
Long overlooked on Europeâ€™s gastronomic map, Ireland is emerging as a top culinary destinationâ€”nowhere more so than in this rugged southwestern corner. County Cork's unique microclimate and creative community has served as fertile ground for culinary invention; and the hills are green nearly all year and shores are laden with seaweed superfoods. Youâ€™ll find Michelin-starred restaurants hiding in villages of just a few hundred people, farmers crafting new kinds of cheese, and wild foragers bringing the native plants of Ireland back to palateâ€¦

entry.title: Why some people are better off sleeping on their sides
entry.summary:
If you struggle with sleep apnea, acid reflux, or back pain, changing how you sleep may offer some relief. Your sleep position can cause everything from back pain to acid reflux. A simple change can improve your health dramatically.
In recent years, a preponderance of research has shown that something as simple as sleeping on your side may be the answer to reducing back pain, heartburn, and sleep apneaâ€”conditions that affect tens of millions of peopleâ€”even if it doesnâ€™t also provide relief to some other issues people think it does.
â€œSide sleeping does have clear benefits over stomach or back sleeping, but only for certain groups of individuals,"Â says Raj Dasgupta, a pulmonary and sleep medicine physician at Huntington Memorial Hospital in California.
Here's what to know â€¦

entry.title: See Lake Como and the Italian Riviera without the crowds
entry.summary: Travelers looking for la dolce vita or the sweet life in Italy should consider a visit to the picturesque town of Menaggio on Lake Como. The three uniquely different towns of Rapallo, Varenna, and Menaggio offer elegant views, food tours and everything you need for your dream vacation. Most world travelers are familiar with the popular and often over-touristed cities in Italy such as Rome, Florence, Milan, and Naples, but there are lesser-known locales found on the Italian Riviera and in the Lake Como area that offer equally authentic experiences in Italian food, art, and cultural history. Hereâ€™s how to plan your dream Italian holiday to three towns in Northwest Italyâ€”without the crowds. Situated on the coast of the Ligurian Sea just south of Genoa and north of Cinqueâ€¦

entry.title: Quebec City offers the charm of Paris without the crowds
entry.summary:
Craving the romance of Paris without the jet lag or legions of other people? The City of Light welcomed nearly 30 million visitors in 2023, and even more admirers plan to travel there since the 2024 Summer Olympics and reopening of the Cathedral of Notre Dame. Canadaâ€™s QuÃ©bec City, a UNESCO World Heritage Site with French roots, emanates European elegance yet welcomes about a fractionÂ of the visitors as Paris. Flights from the United States clock much shorter times too, providing travelers with Old World charm minus the travel fatigue. Â
French, British, and North American cultures weave together in this walkable, refined city. â€œQuÃ©bec City is French-speaking, but itâ€™s North American, and itâ€™s unique,â€ says David Mendel, an author and historian who has lived in Paris and has also resiâ€¦

entry.title: See Sally Rideâ€™s boundary-breaking life in photos
entry.summary:
When pioneering female astronaut Sally Ride died of pancreatic cancer in 2012, a single line in her obituary told the story a lifetime of press coverage and fame had never revealed: her 27-year partnership with another woman, Tam Oâ€™Shaughnessy.
The revelation that Ride was a member of the LGBTQ+ community added another first to her lengthy list of historic accomplishments. She was not just the first American woman to go to spaceâ€”41 years ago on June 18, 1983â€”but the first known queer astronaut.
The revelation added a new dimension to the intense, brilliant physicist, loyal crew member, and passionate science education advocate. And it led some to question what Rideâ€™s life may have been like in a less homophobic, sexist world. Rideâ€™s private journey is uncovered in the award-winniâ€¦

Appendix: AI keywords used in this study
entry.summary: A webpage was classified as containing an AI mention if it had at least one of the following keywords. These keywords were detected using regular expression matching, included common variants and were not case sensitive, unless noted otherwise. The post Appendix: AI keywords used in this study appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The findings in this report are based on an analysis of the browsing behaviors of 900 U.S. adults who are members of the KnowledgePanel Digital online panel, a subset of Ipsosâ€™ KnowledgePanel. These panelists qualified for the study because they: After the March monitoring period, panelistsâ€™ web browsing activity logs were delivered on April 7, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals: Primary researchers Athena Chapekis, Computational Social Science AnalystAnna Lieb, Computational Social Science AssistantSono Shah, Associate Director, Data LabsAaron Smith, Director, Data Labs Research team Regina Widjaya, Computational Social ScientistGalen Stocking, Senior Computational Social ScientistBrian Broderick, Former Senior Data EngineerGonzalo [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: What Web Browsing Data Tells Us About How AI Appears Online
entry.summary: One month of web browsing data shows most respondents visited a search page with an AI-generated summary, but visits to in-depth content about AI were much rarer. The post What Web Browsing Data Tells Us About How AI Appears Online appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Why cancer rates are rising in young womenâ€”and what to do about it
entry.summary:
A PET scan of a female patient with breast cancer, which has spread to the lymph nodes, bones and liver. A recent report found that women account for two-thirds of all cancers diagnosed in people under 50. But it's not all bad news.
In its recent annual report, the American Cancer Society shared some striking news: Cancer is turning up more frequently in young people â€“ especially in young women.Â
Before we panic: The trend is not entirely a new one. Women have long had higher cancer rates than men in younger age groups. And thereâ€™s good news in the report too, says Otis Brawley, an oncologist and epidemiology professor at Johns Hopkins Universityâ€™s Bloomberg School of Public Health. Namely, it found that, overall, cancer deaths have been trending downward.
But the reportâ€¦

entry.title: Been to Barcelona? Now try Spain's lesser-known cities
entry.summary:
Stay a few days to roam the sloping AlbaicÃ­n district, where locals and visitors gather on broad terraces to catch views across terracotta rooftops to the Alhambra, backed by the spectacular Sierra Nevada mountains. Watch flamenco, roam medieval streets and find local tapas haunts in these destination dupes.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With Spain receiving record-breaking numbers of international visitors in the past two years â€” up to 94 million last year â€” it pays to hunt out its quiet corners. And there are plenty of areas where travellers have yet to claim a stake. While major Spanish cities like Barcelona, Madrid and Seville justifiably receive millions of visitors a year, the country is packed with dozens of disarmingly beautiful andâ€¦

entry.title: Why Tateyama Kurobe route is Japanâ€™s ultimate mountain journey
entry.summary:
The journey on Tateyama Kurobe Alpine Route involves travelling by train, bus, funicular, cable car and even a short stretch on foot. This multimodal route through the countryâ€™s Northern Alps is a great alternative to the similar journey around Mount Fuji â€” and one which attracts far fewer visitors.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
For travellers looking to explore the peaks of Japan, it doesnâ€™t get much better than the Tateyama Kurobe Alpine Route, an extraordinary expedition through the countryâ€™s Northern Alps in the centre of the main island of Honshu. Like a similar but far more travelled route around Mount Fuji to the south,Â this itinerary incorporates multiple forms of transport â€” a train, funicular, highland bus, cable car and electric â€¦

entry.title: How one young pharaoh turned Egypt into a superpower
entry.summary:
The death of Queen Hatshepsut opened the door to rebellion in the Levant. After 22 years in power, she disappeared from history and Thutmose III occupied the throne of Egypt alone. A coalition of Canaanite city-states, supported by the Mitanni Empire and rulers of Kadesh, began to rebel against the new pharaoh. It would come to a head in the walled city of Megiddo, in what today is Israel. Sited on the Plain of Esdraelon, the city could control two trade routes of special interest: one connecting with the coastline and the other leading north to Kadesh. As this was Thutmoseâ€™s first military campaign, the pressure on him was considerable.
According to the large propaganda inscription on the walls of Akh Menu (the Temple of Thutmose III at Karnak), the young pharaoh gathered his mâ€¦

entry.summary: The UN refugee agency (UNHCR) on Friday released aÂ statement expressing grave concern over reports that two boats carrying Rohingya refugees sank off the coast of Myanmar earlier this month, with an estimated 427 people dead.

entry.title: Diplomats prepare ground for June conference on two-State solution for Israel and Palestine
entry.summary: Diplomats convened at UN Headquarters in New York on Friday to lay the groundwork for a crucial international conference in June, aimed at advancing global efforts towards achieving a two-State solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict.

entry.title: Escalating violence drives food crisis across eastern DR Congo, warns WFP
entry.summary: As violence intensifies in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), the World Food Programme (WFP)Â warned Friday that food insecurity is worsening both within the country and in neighbouring States, where 140,000 Congolese have fled since January.

entry.title: UN rights chief calls on South Sudanâ€™s warring parties to end renewed fighting
entry.summary: The UN on Friday warned of further deterioration in the human rights situation in South Sudan amid an uptick in hostilities, arbitrary arrests and hate speech since February.

entry.title: Guterres calls on Israel to accept UNâ€™s â€˜detailed, principledâ€™ aid plan for Gaza
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Friday outlined a five-stage plan to provide lifesaving aid to the stricken population of Gaza, making clear the organization will not take part in any scheme that fails to respect international law or basic humanitarian principles.

entry.title: Syrians face staggering needs amid insecurity and healthcare crisis
entry.summary: Millions of people in Syria continue to face mortal danger from unexploded munitions, disease and malnutrition and more international support is urgently required, senior UN aid officials said on Friday.

entry.title: Aid teams highlight growing anxiety in Gaza after food is looted
entry.summary: Long-awaited food supplies have been looted in Gaza overnight while being transported to desperate communities in the war-torn enclave, UN aid teams reported on Friday.

entry.title: In search of â€˜fjakaâ€™â€”the Croatian art of doing nothing
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
This story begins â€” as many good yarns do â€” in a bar. Specifically, Beach Bar Dodo beside Dubrovnikâ€™s seafront, where Iâ€™m sipping beer with a friend. David Farley had sub-let his perfectly nice flat in New York to decamp to Croatia. Whatâ€™s he doing with his days, I ask. Not much, he replies: â€œPerfecting my fjaka.â€
Fjaka, pronounced â€˜fee-akaâ€™, could only have come from a land of sunbaked islands. It is, David explains, no place to go, no place to be. Allowing days to drift and blur. Back in the capital, Zagreb, they make rude jokes about Dalmatians as donkeys, but that misses the point entirely. With fjaka, the region has elevated easy living into an artform.
With no better plans, I decide to embark on a quixotâ€¦

entry.title: Going to the beach is good for your brain, according to science
entry.summary:
There's little more relaxing than spending time at the beachâ€”but what's going on in your brain during a day spent playing in the waves? Scientists are discovering more of the benefits of "blue spaces" like the coast. Visiting the coast can help you relieve stress and get more activeâ€”and it may even change the way you cope with pain.
The coast has long been a place of healing. In 18th-century Europe, doctors prescribed beach time for ailments ranging from tuberculosis to leprosy. Patients spent their days bathing in (and often drinking) mineral-rich sea water, and at night, they fell asleep to the sounds of briny winds and crashing waves.
While elements of this early sea therapy have since been disproven, modern science continues to find that nature is good for us. Researchers â€¦

entry.title: Do dolphins have a language? Scientists are finding new clues.
entry.summary:
Bottlenose dolphins living near Sarasota, Florida have been observed making consistently structured whistles that suggest a common meaning. â€œIf there is a species that we might be able to engage with in some kind of two-way communication, these guys are really good candidates.â€
Dolphins are some of the most vocal animals in our oceans. Their pods are a bustling soundscape of clicks, whistles, and buzzy pulses. What to our ears is a creaking door or a melodic pop is to a dolphin a means to echolocate or communicate.
They even have namesâ€”research has found they use â€˜signature whistlesâ€™ to identify themselves, a sort of vocal version of a humanâ€™s signature. These whistles are produced by one individual and repeated by anotherâ€”â€œJeff, Jeffâ€â€”to initiate or re-establish contact. The â€¦

entry.title: Take this Salvador DalÃ­-inspired road trip through Spain
entry.summary:
Travelers who embark on a road trip to three Salvador DalÃ­-related museums will see the famous surrealist artistâ€™s outdoor sculptures like this one in Port Lligat, Spain. Explore the life and work of the famed surrealist on an immersive trip to the three towns that make up the DalÃ­ Triangle in Spainâ€™s Costa Brava region.
Barcelona was home to world-renowned surrealist artists such as Pablo Picasso and Joan MirÃ³, as well as architect Antoni GaudÃ­â€”whose artistry as a Catalan modernist is present in the cityâ€™s landmarks such as Casa BatllÃ³ and La Sagrada Familia, scheduled to be structurally completed in 2026 after 144 years of construction.Â
Salvador DalÃ­ was also another iconic name in the surrealism movement. His friend circle ranged from David Bowie and John Lennon to Walt Diâ€¦

entry.title: When humpbacks get stuck, their friends stick around to help
Iffy about camping? Hereâ€™s how to dip your toes in.
entry.summary:
Guided camping trips aim to make the outdoors accessible and comfortable for everyone. For families who want to go camping but hesitate at the thought of figuring everything out on their own, guided camping trips can help the experience go smoothly.
â€œOur family loves the outdoors. We just donâ€™t like sleeping in it.â€ This is what I heard my 11-year-old daughter telling another girl on ourÂ campingÂ trip, who had asked where else weâ€™d beenÂ camping. The answer: Nowhere.
My family had stayed in cabins before, and some of our vacations revolved around hiking, but we usually returned to beds and showers at night. Itâ€™s not that we were nervous about sleeping in a tentâ€”we just hadnâ€™t been motivated to buy all the gear and figure it out.
But then my daughters, ages 11 and 15, said tâ€¦
